hawaiian_text: ‘O Hō‘ae‘ae ma ‘Ewa ka ‘āina, ma laila lāua i  launa kino ai me ka moe ‘ana iho ā loa‘a ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o. A hāpai ‘o Pōka‘ī iā   Nāmakaokapāo‘o, ho‘i akula ‘o Kauluakaha‘i i kona  ‘āina, noho ihola ‘o Pōka‘ī me kona hāpai, a ma hope, hānau. Ma kēia hānau ‘ana, he ‘ilihune loa ‘o  Pōka‘ī a me kāna keiki ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o.
kimi-k2-fireworks_translation: Hō'ae'ae in 'Ewa was the land, there they met physically and conceived Nāmakaokapāo'o. When Pōka'ī became pregnant with Nāmakaokapāo'o, Kauluakaha'i returned to his own land, leaving Pōka'ī alone with her pregnancy, and later, she gave birth. In this birthing, Pōka'ī and her child Nāmakaokapāo'o were very poor indeed.
kimi-k2-fireworks_commentary:
**Paragraph 2:** • The narrative has quickly moved from establishing the social identity and lineage of the main protagonist to the circumstances of his conception and birth, which are marked by abandonment and poverty. This represents a classic Hawaiian storytelling device where the greatness of a hero is often emphasized by the adversity of his origins.

• **Place and conception:** – The specific location is given as Hō'ae'ae in 'Ewa. Hō'ae'ae literally means "to become/appear little" or "to shrink" (Pukui & Elbert: *hō'ae'ae*), which carries symbolic weight when we consider the protagonist's description in Paragraph 1 as an extremely strong but "little" (*'u'uku*) boy. This place name foreshadows the physical description of Nāmakaokapāo'o. – The phrase *launa kino ai me ka moe 'ana* (met physically with sleeping) represents a euphemistic way of describing sexual union in Hawaiian narrative, typical of the reserved manner in which such matters were discussed during the 'Ai Kapu era.

• **Parental relationship patterns:** – This passage presents a departure from typical Hawaiian chiefly unions. While Kauluakaha'i is described as a high chief (*ali'i nui*) and demigod in Paragraph 1, here we see a pattern more reminiscent of commoner relationships: conception occurs, but the father leaves. This is significant because in chiefly genealogy, the father's presence and recognition of the child was crucial for legitimacy. – Kauluakaha'i's departure *i kona 'āina* (to his own land) suggests either: 1) a return to Kahikipapaialewa mentioned in Paragraph 1, indicating the union was temporary or politically expedient; or 2) a return to his principal residence within 'Ewa, abandoning Pōka'ī while still being geographically close.

• **Maternal vulnerability:** – The text emphasizes *noho ihola 'o Pōka'ī me kona hāpai* (Pōka'ī remained with her pregnancy [alone]), using the phrase *me kona hāpai* (with her pregnancy) rather than *me kona keiki* (with her child), drawing attention to the burden of pregnancy itself. The word *hāpai* doubles as both physical burden and pregnancy, creating a double meaning of emotional and physical weight. – The final clause *he 'ilihune loa* (very poor indeed) uses the emphatic *loa* (very/extremely) which is somewhat unusual in its intensity. This suggests either absolute deprivation or significant loss of status, as 'ilihune normally describes not just material poverty but lack of social and kinship support. In traditional Hawaiian society, wealth was measured not merely in land or material goods but in reciprocal relationships (*kōkua*) and kinship networks.

• **Theological implication:** – The birth of Nāmakaokapāo'o under these circumstances follows a pattern found in other Hawaiian heroic narratives where divine or semi-divine beings who defy the 'Ai Kapu system are born into situations of social marginality (compare Māui's birth to Hina, abandoned by Hāloa). This suggests that Nāmakaokapāo'o, despite divine paternity, will grow up outside traditional kapu structures, making him free to challenge and eventually transform them.

• **Numerical and calendrical foreshadowing:** – While no explicit numbers are given, Hō'ae'ae in 'Ewa carries calendrical significance in some traditions as marking the beginning of the *Makali'i* (Pleiades) rising period (November), associated with the god Lono and the agricultural cycle. Nāmakaokapāo'o's birth during this agricultural time period foreshadows his relationship with sweet potato cultivation that becomes central to the narrative.
raw_response:
<translation>
Hō'ae'ae in 'Ewa was the land, there they met physically and conceived Nāmakaokapāo'o. When Pōka'ī became pregnant with Nāmakaokapāo'o, Kauluakaha'i returned to his own land, leaving Pōka'ī alone with her pregnancy, and later, she gave birth. In this birthing, Pōka'ī and her child Nāmakaokapāo'o were very poor indeed.
</translation>

<commentary>
**Paragraph 2:** • The narrative has quickly moved from establishing the social identity and lineage of the main protagonist to the circumstances of his conception and birth, which are marked by abandonment and poverty. This represents a classic Hawaiian storytelling device where the greatness of a hero is often emphasized by the adversity of his origins.

• **Place and conception:** – The specific location is given as Hō'ae'ae in 'Ewa. Hō'ae'ae literally means "to become/appear little" or "to shrink" (Pukui & Elbert: *hō'ae'ae*), which carries symbolic weight when we consider the protagonist's description in Paragraph 1 as an extremely strong but "little" (*'u'uku*) boy. This place name foreshadows the physical description of Nāmakaokapāo'o. – The phrase *launa kino ai me ka moe 'ana* (met physically with sleeping) represents a euphemistic way of describing sexual union in Hawaiian narrative, typical of the reserved manner in which such matters were discussed during the 'Ai Kapu era.

• **Parental relationship patterns:** – This passage presents a departure from typical Hawaiian chiefly unions. While Kauluakaha'i is described as a high chief (*ali'i nui*) and demigod in Paragraph 1, here we see a pattern more reminiscent of commoner relationships: conception occurs, but the father leaves. This is significant because in chiefly genealogy, the father's presence and recognition of the child was crucial for legitimacy. – Kauluakaha'i's departure *i kona 'āina* (to his own land) suggests either: 1) a return to Kahikipapaialewa mentioned in Paragraph 1, indicating the union was temporary or politically expedient; or 2) a return to his principal residence within 'Ewa, abandoning Pōka'ī while still being geographically close.

• **Maternal vulnerability:** – The text emphasizes *noho ihola 'o Pōka'ī me kona hāpai* (Pōka'ī remained with her pregnancy [alone]), using the phrase *me kona hāpai* (with her pregnancy) rather than *me kona keiki* (with her child), drawing attention to the burden of pregnancy itself. The word *hāpai* doubles as both physical burden and pregnancy, creating a double meaning of emotional and physical weight. – The final clause *he 'ilihune loa* (very poor indeed) uses the emphatic *loa* (very/extremely) which is somewhat unusual in its intensity. This suggests either absolute deprivation or significant loss of status, as 'ilihune normally describes not just material poverty but lack of social and kinship support. In traditional Hawaiian society, wealth was measured not merely in land or material goods but in reciprocal relationships (*kōkua*) and kinship networks.

• **Theological implication:** – The birth of Nāmakaokapāo'o under these circumstances follows a pattern found in other Hawaiian heroic narratives where divine or semi-divine beings who defy the 'Ai Kapu system are born into situations of social marginality (compare Māui's birth to Hina, abandoned by Hāloa). This suggests that Nāmakaokapāo'o, despite divine paternity, will grow up outside traditional kapu structures, making him free to challenge and eventually transform them.

• **Numerical and calendrical foreshadowing:** – While no explicit numbers are given, Hō'ae'ae in 'Ewa carries calendrical significance in some traditions as marking the beginning of the *Makali'i* (Pleiades) rising period (November), associated with the god Lono and the agricultural cycle. Nāmakaokapāo'o's birth during this agricultural time period foreshadows his relationship with sweet potato cultivation that becomes central to the narrative.
</commentary>
reference_translation: Hō‘ae‘ae is the place in ‘Ewa, where the two  met in person and slept together and conceived  Nāmakaokapāo‘o. When Pōka‘ī became pregnant,  Kauluakaha‘i went home to where he came from,  and Pōka‘ī throughout her pregnancy and later gave birth. When she gave birth, Pōka‘ī and her  child, Nāmakaokapāo‘o lived in poverty.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 2:**• Hō-‘ae‘ae (to make smoothe) in ‘Ewa (error,  misjudgment) is where Kauluakaha‘i (m) and Pōka‘ī  (f) met, slept together, and where Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o was born. When Pō-ka-‘ī became pregnant, Ka ulu-a-kaha‘i left and returned to his home in Kahiki papa-ia-lewa. Pō-ka-‘ī was single and destitute when  she gave birth to Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o.
